revision.text:
[[File:Backscatter large.jpg|thumb|Backscatter technology produces an image that resembles a chalk etching.{{Citation|url=http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/how_it_works.shtm |publisher=TSA |title=How it works |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203034020/http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/how_it_works.shtm |archivedate=December 3, 2010 }}]] '''Backscatter X-ray''' is an advanced [[X-ray imaging]] technology. Traditional [[X-ray machine]]s detect hard and soft materials by the variation in [[x-ray]] intensity transmitted through the target. In contrast, backscatter X-ray detects the radiation that [[backscatter|reflects]] from the target. It has potential applications where less-destructive examination is required, and can operate even if only one side of the target is available for examination. The technology is one of two types of whole-body imaging technologies that have been used to perform [[Full body scanner|full-body scans]] of airline passengers to detect hidden weapons, tools, liquids, narcotics, currency, and other contraband. A competing technology is [[millimeter wave scanner]]. One can refer to an [[airport security]] machine of this type as a "body scanner", "whole body imager (WBI)", "security scanner" or "naked scanner". {{cite web |place=[[United Kingdom|UK]] |url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/11/29/oukin-uk-germany-bodyscanner-idUKTRE4AS1V320081129 |title=Germany plans lab tests for airport naked scans | Reuters |publisher= Reuters |date=2008-11-29 |accessdate= 2013-09-03 }} ==Deployments at airports== In the United States, the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 required that all full-body scanners operated in airports by the [[Transportation Security Administration]] use "Automated Target Recognition" software, which replaces the picture of a nude body with the cartoon-like representation.{{cite news |url= https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/01/tsa-abandons-nude-scanners/|title=TSA Pulls Plug on Airport Nude Body Scanners |date= 2013-01-18| first=David | last=Kravets}} As a result of this law, all backscatter X-ray machines formerly in use by the Transportation Security Administration were removed from airports by May 2013, since the agency said the vendor (Rapiscan) did not meet their contractual deadline to implement the software.{{Citation | title = Rapiscan backscatter contract | date=Jan 2013 | publisher=TSA | format= [[World wide Web]] log | url= http://blog.tsa.gov/2013/01/rapiscan-backscatter-contract.html}}. In the European Union, backscatter X-ray screening of airline passengers was banned in 2012 to protect passenger safety, and the deployment at [[Manchester Airport]] was removed.{{cite news |agency= Daily Mail | place=UK |date= 2013-05-30 |title=TSA pulls ALL X-ray body scanners from airports over privacy concerns... but claims they were never a health risk to fliers |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2333685/TSA-removes-ALL-backscatter-X-ray-machines-airports-privacy-concerns.html}} ==Technology== Backscatter technology is based on the [[Compton scattering]] effect of [[X-rays]], a form of [[ionizing radiation]]. Unlike a traditional X-ray machine, which relies on the transmission of X-rays through the object, backscatter X-ray detects the radiation that reflects from the object and forms an image. The backscatter pattern is dependent on the material property and is good for imaging organic material. In contrast to [[millimeter wave scanner]]s, which create a 3D image, backscatter X-ray scanners will typically only create a 2D image. For airport screening, images are taken from both sides of the human body.{{cite web|url=http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/imaging_technology.shtm |title=Imaging Technology |publisher=Transportation Security Administration |accessdate=December 31, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106043039/http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/imaging_technology.shtm |archivedate=6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Backscatter X-ray was first applied in a commercial low-dose personnel scanning system by Dr. Steven W. Smith.{{US patent reference | number = 5181234 | y = 1993 | m = 01 | d = 19 | inventor = Steven W. Smith | title = X-ray Backscatter Detection System}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tek84.com/company.html |title=Steven W. Smith / Original Developer of Secure 1000 in 1992 |publisher=Tek84.com |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908095734/http://www.tek84.com/company.html |archivedate=8 September 2010 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite news|last= Hamilton |first= Jon |title= New Airport Body Scans Don't Detect All Weapons|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=122499686 |accessdate= November 12, 2010|newspaper=NPR|date=January 14, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101112095458/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=122499686 | archivedate= 12 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Smith developed the Secure 1000 whole-body scanner in 1992 and then sold the device and associated patents to Rapiscan Systems, who now manufactures and distributes the device. The following companies manufacture commercial backscatter X-ray devices that are used in security scanning applications with price ranging from $250,000 to $2,000,000: # Heuresis Corporation (device name: HBI-120){{Cite web|url=https://www.heuresistech.com/hbi120|title=HBI-120 Handheld X-Ray Imager {{!}} Heuresis|website=www.heuresistech.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}} #[[Rapiscan Systems]], a subsidiary of OSI Systems Inc.{{US patent reference | number = 7826589 | y = 2008 | m = 12 | d = 24 | title = Security System for Screening People}}{{Citation | title = Rapiscan | url = http://www.rapiscansystems.com/}}. (device name: Secure 1000) # [[American Science and Engineering]]{{Citation | title = AS&E | url = http://www.as-e.com/}}. (device name: Smartcheck) # Tek84 Engineering Group LLC, formerly Spectrum San Diego Inc.{{Citation|title=tek84 |url=http://www.tek84.com/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418053454/http://www.tek84.com/ |archivedate=2010-04-18 |df= }}. (device name: AIT84 Body Scanner & Castscope) # Nucsafe Inc.{{Citation | title = Nucsafe | url = http://www.nucsafe.com/}}. (device name: Backscatter X-Ray RSD System) == Large scale ==
{{Gallery |width=120 | height=120 |File:rvacis_scan.png|RVACIS |File:rapiscan_gards.png|Rapiscan GaRDS |File:mobile_search_xray.png|Mobile Search |File:zbv_van1.png|ZBV, by AS&E |File:mvacis.png|MVACIS (Gamma Ray)}}
Some backscatter X-ray scanners can scan much larger objects, such as trucks and containers. This scan is much faster than a physical search and could potentially allow a larger percentage of shipping to be checked for smuggled items, weapons, drugs, or people.{{cite web|url=http://www.as-e.com/products_solutions/ |publisher=AS&E |title=inspection products and solutions |accessdate=August 16, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The "Z Backscatter Van", or ZBV, from AS&E is a mobile backscatter X-ray machine in a van, which "from the outside looks like an ordinary delivery van, allowing it to blend in to urban and other landscapes". It is being promoted as a means of examining the contents of vehicles, containers, and dumpsters. Unlike many of the truck-based scanners, it has no "arm" that deploys from the van to be able to scan other vehicles passing through, therefore allowing larger items and objects to be scanned in comparison to the limitations in width and height of "scanning arms".{{cite web | website = You tube | type = video |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iABPKd0vFxQ |title=AS&E Z Backsctter Van Promotional Video}} Other companies in the industry are Smiths Detection and Rapiscan.{{Citation | url = http://www.gao.gov/mobile/content?path=decisions/bidpro/4021686.htm | title = GAO | date = 9 Feb 2011}}. There are also [[gamma-ray]]-based systems coming to market, like the MVACIS.{{Citation|title=NII Non-Intrusive Inspection, JPE-CBD, US Army Project Manager – Force Protection Systems, IED Threat Detection |format=pdf |url=http://www.jpeocbd.osd.mil/fps/Docs/Brochure%20for%20NII%20Aug2008.pdf |publisher=OSD |date=Aug 2008 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928211825/http://www.jpeocbd.osd.mil/fps/Docs/Brochure%20for%20NII%20Aug2008.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-28 |df= }}. In May 2011, the [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]] filed suit against the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) under the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]], claiming that DHS had withheld nearly 1000 pages of documents related to the Z backscatter vans and other mobile backscatter devices.{{cite web|url= http://epic.org/privacy/body_scanners/Mobile_Body_Scanner_Complaint.pdf |title=Mobile Body Scanner Complaint|publisher= Electronic Privacy Information Center | format = PDF |accessdate= 2013-09-03}} ==Concerns== {{See also|Full body scanner#Controversies}} {{cleanup |section|date=November 2010}} ===Legality=== Since in addition to weapons, these machines are designed to be capable of detecting drugs, currency and contraband, which have no direct effect on airport security and passenger safety, some have argued that the use of these full body scanners is a violation of the [[4th Amendment to the United States Constitution]] and can be construed as an illegal search and seizure.{{cite web|url= https://epic.org/privacy/airtravel/backscatter/ | website = Epic | title= Whole Body Imaging Technology and Body Scanners ("Backscatter" X-Ray and Millimeter Wave Screening) |accessdate= 2014-03-23}} ===Privacy=== [[File:Backscatter x-ray image woman.jpg|thumb|upright|An image of Susan Hallowell, Director of the Transportation Security Administration's research lab taken with backscatter x-ray system.]] Backscatter x-ray technology has been proposed as an alternative to personal searches at airport and other security checkpoints easily penetrating clothing to reveal concealed weapons. It raises privacy concerns about what is seen by the person viewing the scan. Some{{Who |date=November 2015}} worry that viewing the image violates confidential medical information, such as the fact a passenger uses a [[colostomy bag]], has a missing limb or wears a prosthesis, or is transgender. The [[ACLU]] and the [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]] are opposed to this use of the technology. The ACLU refers to backscatter x-rays as a "virtual strip search".{{cite web|url= https://www.aclu.org/technology-and-liberty/aclu-backgrounder-body-scanners-and-virtual-strip-searches |title=ACLU Backgrounder on Body Scanners and "Virtual Strip Searches" |publisher= ACLU |date=January 8, 2010}} According to the [[Transportation Security Administration]] (TSA), in one trial 79 percent of the public opted to try backscatter over the traditional pat-down in secondary screening.{{cite web |url=http://www.tsa.gov/press/releases/2007/press_release_10112007.shtm |title=TSA Tests Second Passenger Imaging Technology at Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport |publisher=TSA |date=October 11, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815095917/http://www.tsa.gov/press/releases/2007/press_release_10112007.shtm |archivedate=15 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It is "possible for backscatter X-raying to produce photo-quality images of what's going on beneath our clothes", thus, many software implementations of the scan have been designed to distort private areas.{{Citation | last = Layton | first = Julia | title = Do 'Backscatter' X-Ray Systems Pose a Risk to Frequent Fliers? | publisher = HowStuffWorks | date = 27 February 2007 | accessdate = 18 March 2007 | url = http://travel.howstuffworks.com/backscatter.htm | series = "Backscatter" X-Ray Screening Technology}}. According to the TSA, further distortion is used in the Phoenix airport's trial system where photo-quality images are replaced by chalk outlines.[http://www.tsa.gov/research/privacy/faqs.shtm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427205030/http://www.tsa.gov/research/privacy/faqs.shtm |date=April 27, 2007 }}{{cite news |first=William |last=Salatan |title=Digital Penetration |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2160977/}} The TSA has also commented that screening procedures such as having the screener viewing the image located far away from the person being screened could be a possibility.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} In light of this, some journalists have expressed concern that this blurring may allow people to carry weapons or certain explosives aboard by attaching the object or substance to their genitals.{{Citation | publisher = Electronic Privacy Information Center | date = 18 Mar 2007 | contribution = Backscatter | title = Air travel piracy | contribution-url = http://www.epic.org/privacy/airtravel/backscatter}}. The British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' has revealed concern among British officials that the use of such scanners to scan children may be illegal under the [[Protection of Children Act 1978]], which prohibits the creation and distribution of indecent images of children. This concern may delay the introduction of routine backscatter scanning in UK airports, which had been planned in response to the attempted Christmas Day 2009 attack on [[Northwest Airlines Flight 253]].{{cite news | first=Alan | last= Travis | title=New scanners break child porn laws | date=January 4, 2009 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/jan/04/new-scanners-child-porn-laws | work =[[The Guardian]] | accessdate = January 6, 2010 | location= London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100106020852/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2010/jan/04/new-scanners-child-porn-laws | archivedate= 6 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} The [[Fiqh Council of North America]] have also issued the following [[fatwa]] in relation to full-body scanners: {{quote|It is a violation of clear Islamic teachings that men or women be seen naked by other men and women. Islam highly emphasizes haya (modesty) and considers it part of faith. The Quran has commanded the believers, both men and women, to cover their private parts.{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2010/02/fatwa-forbids-muslims-going-through-full-body-scanners/1 |title= 'Fatwa' forbids Muslims going through full-body scanners | newspaper = USA today |date= February 12, 2010 |accessdate= August 16, 2010}}}} In August 2010, it was reported{{cite news|url= http://video.foxnews.com/v/4303191/peep-show-database-of-american-travelers/?playlist_id=86919 |title= 'Peep Show Database of American Travelers' — Video | work = [[Fox News]] |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}{{who|date=September 2013}} that U.S. Marshals (part of the Department of Justice),{{cite web| last=Lundin|first= Leigh |title= You show me yours and … |url= http://www.criminalbrief.com/?p=13511|website=Florida News |publisher=Criminal Brief |location= Orlando |date= August 15, 2010 |quote=Remember Homeland Security told the public the scanners aren’t capable of storing images? Someone forgot to tell the scanner at the federal courthouse in Orlando…}} saved thousands of images from a low resolution [[Millimeter wave scanner|MM wave scanner]]: This machine does not show details of human anatomy, and is a different kind of machine from the one used in airports. TSA, part of the Department of Homeland Security, said that its scanners do not save images and that the scanners do not have the capability to save images when they are installed in airports,{{cite web|url= http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/08/tsa-response-to-feds-admit-storing.html | website =The TSA Blog | title = TSA Response to "Feds admit storing checkpoint body scan images" |publisher= TSA |date=June 8, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100816125439/http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/08/tsa-response-to-feds-admit-storing.html| archivedate= 16 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} but later admitted that the scanners are required to be capable of saving images for the purpose of evaluation, training and testing.{{cite web|last=Quinn |first= Rob |url= http://www.newser.com/story/97427/feds-admit-storing-body-scans.html |title=Feds Admit Storing Body Scans |publisher= Newser |date= August 6, 2010 |accessdate=November 20, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101114061829/http://www.newser.com/story/97427/feds-admit-storing-body-scans.html| archivedate= 14 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Shahid |first=Aliyah |url= http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2010/08/04/2010-08-04_feds_admit_they_stored_body_scanner_images_despite_tsa_claim_the_images_cannot_b.html |title= Feds admit they stored body scanner images, despite TSA claim the images cannot be saved |publisher= NY Daily News |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=November 20, 2010 |location=New York}} ===Health effects=== Unlike cell phone signals, or millimeter-wave scanners, the energy being emitted by a backscatter X-ray is a type of [[ionizing radiation]] that breaks chemical bonds. Ionizing radiation is considered carcinogenic [[Linear no-threshold model|even in very small doses]] but at the doses used in airport scanners this effect is believed to be negligible for an individual.{{cite journal | first1 = Leon | last1 = Mullenders | first2 = Mike | last2 = Atkinson | first3 = Herwig | last3 = Paretzke | first4 = Laure | last4 = Sabatier | first5 = Simon | last5 = Bouffler | title = Assessing cancer risks of low-dose radiation | journal = Nature Reviews Cancer | volume = 9 | issue = 8 | pages = 596–604 | year = 2009 | doi=10.1038/nrc2677 | pmid=19629073}}{{Citation | publisher = Health Physics Society | year = 2004 | title = Radiation Risk in Perspective | id = PS010-2 | url = http://hps.org/documents/risk_ps010-2.pdf | format = PDF | quote = Below 5–10 rem (which includes occupational and environmental exposures), risks of health effects are either too small to be observed or are nonexistent.}}{{Citation | publisher = The American Nuclear Society | year = 2001 | title = Health Effects of Low-Level Radiation | series = Position Statement | number = 41 | url = http://www.ans.org/pi/ps/docs/ps41.pdf | format = PDF}}.{{cite web|author=25 November 2010 |url= http://hps.org/newsandevents/newsarchive/oldnews497.html | website =Society News Archive | title = BEIR VII Report Supports LNT Model |publisher= HPS |accessdate=November 25, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101216012123/http://hps.org/newsandevents/newsarchive/oldnews497.html| archivedate= 16 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} If 1 million people were exposed to 520 scans in one year, one study estimated that roughly four additional cancers would occur due to the scanner, in contrast to the 600 additional cancers that would occur from the higher levels of radiation during flight.{{cite journal|last1 =Mehta|first1 =P| last2= Smith-Bindman | first2 = R|title= Airport Full-Body Screening: What Is the Risk?|journal= Archives of Internal Medicine |date= 2011-03-28|pmid=21444831|doi=10.1001/archinternmed.2011.105|volume= 171|issue= 12 |pages= 1112–5|pmc=3936792}} Since the scanners do not have a medical purpose, the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) does not need to subject them to the same safety evaluations as medical X-rays.{{cite web |url=https://www.propublica.org/article/u.s.-government-glossed-over-cancer-concerns-as-it-rolled-out-airport-x-ray |title=U.S. Government Glossed Over Cancer Concerns As It Rolled Out Airport X-Ray Scanners |publisher= Pro publica | date=November 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 18, 2011}} However, the FDA has created a webpage comparing known estimates of the radiation from backscatter X-ray body scanners to that of other known sources, which cites various reasons they deem the technology to be safe.{{cite web |url= http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/SecuritySystems/ucm227201.htm |title=Products for Security Screening of People |publisher=FDA |accessdate=November 25, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101122125552/http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/SecuritySystems/ucm227201.htm| archivedate= 22 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Four professors at the [[University of California, San Francisco]], among them members of NAS and an expert in cancer and imaging, in an April 2010 letter{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/assets/news/2010/05/17/concern.pdf |title= Letter of Concern|accessdate= November 26, 2010| first = John | last = Sedat |date= April 6, 2010| format = PDF |publisher= NPR |page= 4 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101126050314/http://www.npr.org/assets/news/2010/05/17/concern.pdf| archivedate= 26 November 2010 | deadurl= no |display-authors= etal}} to the [[John Holdren|presidential science and technology advisor]] raised several concerns about the validity of the indirect comparisons the [[Food and Drug Administration]] used in evaluating the safety of backscatter x-ray machines.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126833083 |title=Scientists Question Safety Of New Airport Scanners|publisher= NPR |accessdate= November 7, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101113055500/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126833083| archivedate= 13 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} They argued that the effective dose is higher than claimed by the TSA and the body scanner manufacturers because the dose was calculated as if distributed throughout the whole body, whereas most of the radiation is absorbed in the skin and tissues immediately underneath. Other professors from the radiology department at UCSF disagree with the claims of the signing four professors.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sfweekly.com/thesnitch/2010/11/tsa_scanner_controversy_ucsf_r.php|title=TSA Scanners: U.C. San Francisco Radiologists Debunk Radiation Fears| first =Lauren | last = Smiley| website = The snitch | publisher = SF Weekly}} The UCSF professors requested that additional data be made public detailing the specific data regarding sensitive areas, such as the skin and certain organs, as well as data on the special (high-risk) population. In October 2010, the FDA and TSA responded to these concerns.{{cite web |last= Holdren |first= John P |title= Response to University of California — San Francisco Regarding Their Letter of Concern, October 12, 2010 |url= http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/SecuritySystems/ucm231857.htm |publisher= Office of Science and Technology Policy |accessdate= November 12, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101112022237/http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/SecuritySystems/ucm231857.htm | archivedate= 12 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web |last=Larson |first=Phil |title= Backscatter Back-Story |url= http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/11/08/backscatter-back-story |publisher=Office of Science and Technology Policy |accessdate=November 12, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101112053543/http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/11/08/backscatter-back-story| archivedate= 12 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} The letter cites reports which show that the specific dose to the skin is some 89,000 times lower than the annual limit to the skin established by the [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements|NCRP]]. Regarding the UCSF concerns over the high-risk population to sensitive organs, the letter states that such an individual "would have to receive more than 1,000 screenings to begin to approach the annual limit".FDA & NIST Assessment (2006); ''Our dose modeling reveals that a screening that delivers 0.25 µSv effective dose would deliver approximately 0.12 µSv to the uterus or 0.69 µSv to the testes.''{{Citation | publisher= NCRP |series= Statement |number = 10 |title=Recent Applications of the NCRP Public Dose Limit Recommendation for Ionizing Radiation | year=2004}}.{{Citation |publisher= NCRP |type= report | number=116 |title= Limitation of exposure to ionizing radiation}}. John Sedat, the principal author of the UCSF letter, responded in November 2010 that the White House's claim that full-body scanners pose no health risks to air travelers is in "error," adding that the White House statement has "many misconceptions, and we will write a careful answer pointing out their errors."{{cite web |last=McCullagh |first=Declan |url= http://news.cnet.com/8301-31921_3-20022541-281.html#ixzz155dhfUQO |title= Biochemist says 'naked' X-ray scanner may be unsafe | Privacy Inc | publisher = CNET | website = News | accessdate=November 25, 2010}} In a December 2, 2010 letter to the House of Representatives, Dr. Steven Smith, inventor of the body scanner in 1991, stated that the concerns of Brenner and UCSF regarding the skin dose of backscatter scanners is incorrect and the result of a confusion between dose and imaging penetration. Smith demonstrated this difference with two experiments using plastic (with a similar [[Attenuation coefficient|rate of absorption]] as body tissue), copper (the image subject), and an x-ray scanner. The dose-penetration experiment shows that {{cvt|5|and|50|mm|in}} plastic samples absorb 5% and 50% of the beam intensity respectively, whereas the imaging penetration experiment shows that {{cvt|4.8|and|10|mm}} plastic samples reduce the image darkness by 23% and 50% respectively. Dr. Smith states that those who calculate high skin dosage have incorrectly used the shallow imaging penetration value of a few millimeters (~{{cvt|4|mm|disp=out}}), whereas the actual dosage is calculated by the deeper dose penetration.{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Steven |url=http://www.tek84.com/downloads/Holt-Letter2010-12-2.pdf |format=PDF |date=2010-12-02 |title=Re: Misinformation on airport body scanner radiation safety |publisher=Tek 84 |website=C net |accessdate=December 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716203604/http://www.tek84.com/downloads/Holt-Letter2010-12-2.pdf |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }} The TSA has also made public various independent safety assessments of the Secure 1000 Backscatter X-ray Scanner.{{cite web|title=Safety study AIT info Memo |format=PDF |url=http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/tsa_safety_study_ait_info_memo.pdf |publisher=TSA |accessdate=November 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215113224/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/tsa_safety_study_ait_info_memo.pdf |archivedate=December 15, 2011 }}{{cite web|title=Radiation Engineering Assessment Report |format=PDF |url=http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v1.pdf |publisher=Johns Hopkins University |accessdate=November 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205092128/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v1.pdf |archivedate=February 5, 2011 }}{{cite web|title=Radiation Safety Engineering Assessment Report |format=PDF |url=http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v2.pdf |publisher=Johns Hopkins University |accessdate=November 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419204023/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v2.pdf |archivedate=April 19, 2011 }}{{cite journal|last=Cerra|first=Frank|title=Assessment of the Rapiscan Secure 1000 Bodyscanner for Conformance with Radiological Safety Standards|publisher=NIST}} Radiation safety authorities including the [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements]], The Health Physics Society and the [[American College of Radiology]], have stated that there is no specific evidence that full-body scans are unsafe.{{Citation | date = Mar 2010 | url = http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/03/advanced-imaging-technology-radiation.html | newspaper = The TSA Blog | title = Advanced Imaging Technology: "Radiation Risk Tiny | publisher = TSA | accessdate = 2010-09-26}}. The Secure 1000 Backscatter X-ray scanner was developed in 1992 by Dr. Steve Smith. The scanner has been studied extensively for almost 20 years by the leading independent radiation safety authorities in the United States.{{Citation|title=AIT |type=fact sheet |publisher=TSA |url=http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/ait_fact_sheet.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213235619/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/ait_fact_sheet.pdf |archivedate=December 13, 2010 }} Experimental and epidemiological data do not support the proposition, however, that there is a threshold dose of radiation below which there is no increased risk of cancer.{{Cite journal | last1 = Upton | first1 = AC | year = 2003 | title = The state of the art in the 1990s: NCRP report No. 136 on the scientific bases for linearity in the dose-response relationship for ionizing radiation | url = | journal = Health Physics | volume = 85 | issue = 1| pages = 15–22 | doi=10.1097/00004032-200307000-00005 | pmid=12852466}} The UK Health Protection Agency has completed an analysis of the X-ray dose from backscatter scanners and has written that the dose is extremely low and "about the same as people receive from [[background radiation]] in an hour".{{cite web | place = UK |url= http://www.hpa.org.uk/Topics/Radiation/UnderstandingRadiation/UnderstandingRadiationTopics/BodyScanners/ |title=Body scanning at airports |publisher=HPA |accessdate= November 25, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101124060136/http://www.hpa.org.uk/Topics/Radiation/UnderstandingRadiation/UnderstandingRadiationTopics/BodyScanners/ | archivedate= 24 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} The [[Health Physics Society]] (HPS) reports that a person undergoing a backscatter scan receives approximately 0.05 [[sievert|μSv]] (or 0.005 [[Röntgen equivalent man|mrems]]) of radiation; American Science and Engineering Inc. reports 0.09 μSv (0.009 mrems). At the high altitudes typical of commercial flights, naturally occurring cosmic radiation is considerably higher than at ground level. The radiation dose for a six-hour flight is 20 μSv (2 mrems)—200 to 400 times larger than a backscatter scan. The [[U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Agency]] limits radiation exposure to the public to less than 100 mrem (1 mSv) per year from [[nuclear power plant]]s.{{cite web |url= https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/cfr/part020/part020-1301.html |title= NRC: 10 CFR 20.1301 Dose limits for individual members of the public |publisher=NRC |accessdate= 2013-09-02}} While this is not specifically for airline-associated radiation, the limit is an effective proxy for understanding what level is deemed safe by a regulatory agency. According to a draft{{update inline|date=March 2014}} standard on the United States FDA website, the allowable dose from a scan would be 0.1 μSv, and that report uses a model whereby a 0.01 μSv dose increases an individual's risk of death by cancer during his or her lifetime by {{val|5|e=−10}}.{{cite web |url= http://www.fda.gov/OHRMS/DOCKETS/AC/01/briefing/3751b1_06b.pdf |title=Draft Standard for Personnel Screening Systems}} Since the dose limit is ten times higher than 0.01 μSv, their model would predict one additional cancer death per 200 million scans. Since the airports in the UK handled 218 million passengers in 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/80/airport_data/200911/Table_01_Size_of_UK_Airports.pdf |title=Size of Reporting Airports December 2008 — November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207155633/http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/80/airport_data/200911/Table_01_Size_of_UK_Airports.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-07 |df= }} if all passengers in the UK were scanned at the maximum dosage, then each year this would produce on average one additional cancer death (since there would be 200 million scans per year that the scanners were in operation), though usually each death would not occur in the same year as the particular scan that caused it, since the cancer may take years to grow. In addition, additional people would be given cancer but would die from other causes. There may not yet be evidence of hereditary effects of x-rays administered by backscatter scanners, but backscatter scanners use the same kind of x-ray photons as are produced in medical x-ray machines but expose the subject at a considerably lower dose, so it is possible that the results from medical radiology may be relevant, at least until a study is done of any effects specific to backscatter x-ray machines. Fathers exposed to medical diagnostic x-rays are more likely to have infants who contract leukemia, especially if exposure is closer to conception or includes two or more X-rays of the lower gastrointestinal (GI) tract or lower abdomen.{{cite journal | last1 =Shu | first1 = XO | last2 = Reaman | first2 = GH | last3 = Lampkin | first3 = B | last4 = Sather | first4 = HN | last5 = Pendergrass | first5 = TW | last6 = Robison | first6 = LL |title=Association of paternal diagnostic X-ray exposure with risk of infant leukemia. Investigators of the Childrens Cancer Group |journal= Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention |volume= 3 |issue= 8 |pages= 645–53 |date=December 1994 |pmid= 7881337 |url=http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7881337}} In medical radiography the x-ray beam is adjusted to expose only the area of which an image is required, so that generally shielding is applied to the patient to avoid exposing the gonads,{{cite web|url=http://www.epos.efort.org/public/Sorrentoeposters/3958.ppt |title=The Gonad Shield in Pelvic X-Rays: Covering a Multitude of Sins? : Booth Hall Children's Hospital, Central Manchester and Manchester Children's University Hospitals NHS Trust |place=Manchester, [[England|ENG]], UK |publisher=Effort |format=[[Microsoft|MS]] [[Powerpoint|PPT]] |accessdate=2013-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313162554/http://www.epos.efort.org/public/Sorrentoeposters/3958.ppt |archivedate=2012-03-13 |df= }} whereas in an airport backscatter scan, the testicles of men and boys will be deliberately subjected to the direct beam in order to check for weapons in the underpants, and some radiation will also reach the ovaries of female subjects. A linear dose-response relationship has been observed between x-ray dose and double-strand breaks in DNA in human sperm.{{cite journal | last1 =Singh | first1 = NP | last2 = Stephens | first2 = RE |title= X-ray induced DNA double-strand breaks in human sperm |journal= Mutagenesis |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=75–9 |date= January 1998 |pmid=9491398 |doi= 10.1093/mutage/13.1.75}} Extrapolations of cancer risk from minuscule exposures to radiation across large populations, however, are not supported by analysis by the [[National Council on Radiation Protection]] (NCRP). On May 26, 2010 NCRP issued a press release to address such comments about full body scanners that are compliant with ANSI N43.17. In Commentary No.16 issued on May 26, 2010, it reads as follows: {{Quote | As stated in NCRP Report No. 121 (1995), Principles and Application of Collective Dose in Radiation Protection, the summation of trivial average risks over very large populations or time periods into a single value produces a distorted image of risk, completely out of perspective with risks accepted every day, both voluntarily and involuntarily.}} According to NCRP, the use of statistical extrapolations that predict 1 death for every 200 million persons scanned for example (as above) is an unrealistic over-estimation.{{cite web | website = Commentary | number = 16 | title = Screening of Humans for Security Purposes Using Ionizing Radiation Scanning Systems |url= http://www.ncrppublications.org/Commentaries/16|publisher= National Council on Radiation Protection & Measurements |accessdate=November 12, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101114004428/http://www.ncrppublications.org/Commentaries/16| archivedate= 14 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{Subscription required}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ncrponline.org/Press_Rel/Commentaries/Comm_16_Press_Release.pdf | publisher = NCRP |title=Structural Shielding Design and Evaluation for Megavoltage Radiotherapy Facilities |format=PDF |accessdate=August 16, 2010}} Other scientists at [[Columbia University]] have made the following statements in support of the safety of body scanners:{{Citation | url = http://www.businessweek.com/lifestyle/content/healthday/634724.html | title = Airport Full Body Scanners Pose No Health Threat: Experts | newspaper = Business Week | date = 2010-01-08 | accessdate = 2010-09-26}}. {{Quote | ‘A passenger would need to be scanned using a backscatter scanner, from both the front and the back, about 200,000 times to receive the amount of radiation equal to one typical CT scan,’ said Dr. Andrew J. Einstein, director of cardiac CT research at Columbia University Medical Center in New York City. ´Another way to look at this is that if you were scanned with a backscatter scanner every day of your life, you would still only receive a tenth of the dose of a typical CT scan,’ he said. By comparison, the amount of radiation from a backscatter scanner is equivalent to about 10 minutes of natural background radiation in the United States, Einstein said. ´I believe that the general public has nothing to worry about in terms of the radiation from airline scanning,’ he added. For moms-to-be, no evidence supports an increased risk of miscarriage or fetal abnormalities from these scanners, Einstein added. ‘A pregnant woman will receive much more radiation from cosmic rays she is exposed to while flying than from passing through a scanner in the airport,’ he said.}} Furthermore, other scientists claim the health effects of backscatter are well understood whereas those from [[millimeter wave scanner]]s are not: {{Quote | ‘From a radiation standpoint there has been no evidence that there is really any untoward effect from the use of this device [backscatter scanner], so I would not be concerned about it from a radiation dose standpoint – the issues of personal privacy are a different thing,’ he said. The health effects of the more common [[millimeter wave scanner]] are largely unknown, and at least one expert believes a safety study is warranted. ‘I am very interested in performing a National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements study on the use of millimeter-wave security screening systems,’ said Thomas S. Tenforde, council president. However, no long-term studies have been done on the health effects of millimeter wave scanners.}} Experts evaluating backscatter x-ray machine technology have also argued that defects in the machines, damage from normal wear-and-tear, or software errors could focus an intense dose of radiation on just one spot of the body. For example, Dr. Peter Rez, a professor of physics at Arizona State University, has said, "The thing that worries me the most, is not what happens if the machine works as advertised, but what happens if it doesn't," adding that a potential malfunction of the machine could increase the radiation dose.{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TRAVEL/11/12/body.scanning.radiation/index.html?hpt=T2 | work= CNN | title=Airport body-scan radiation under scrutiny | date=November 12, 2010}}{{cite web |url= http://rpd.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2010/11/09/rpd.ncq358.abstract|title= The Dose From Compton Backscatter Screening|accessdate= November 26, 2010 | first1 = Peter | last1 = Rez | first2=Robert I | last2 = Metzger | first3=Kenneth L | last3 = Mossman |date= November 2010|website= Radiation Protection Dosimetry |publisher= Oxford Journals}} The designers and manufacturers of backscatter X-ray scanners claim that the scanners are designed to prevent the occurrence of these kinds of errors. The scanners' safety requirements include fail-safe controls and multiple overlapping interlocks. These features, combined with fault analysis, ensure that failure of any subsystem results in non-operation of the x-ray generator to prevent accidental exposures. In the United States, the TSA requires that certification to the ANSI N43.17 safety standard is performed by a third party and not by the manufacturer themselves.{{Citation | publisher = ANSI | title = N43.17 | year = 2009 | at = sections 7.2.1 and 7.2.2}}. The [[European Commission]] issued a report stating that backscatter x-ray scanners pose no known health risk, and that "assuming all other conditions equal", that backscatter x-ray scanners, which expose people to ionizing radiation, should not be used when millimeter-wave scanners that "have less effects on the human body" are available.{{cite web | publisher = Rise project | place = [[Europe|EU]] |url= http://www.riseproject.eu/_fileupload/ETHICS%20OF%20BODY%20SCANNER%20POLICY%20REPORT%20NEW.pdf |title= Ethics of Body Scanner Policy Report | at = bullet 3 on p. 6/47 |format= PDF |accessdate=August 16, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100821110646/http://www.riseproject.eu/_fileupload/ETHICS%20OF%20BODY%20SCANNER%20POLICY%20REPORT%20NEW.pdf | archivedate= 21 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} However, the European Commission report provides no data substantiating its claim that "all other conditions are equal". One area where backscatter X-ray scanners can provide better performance than MM wave scanners, for example, is in the inspection of the shoes, groin and armpit regions of the body.{{cite web|url=http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner-more.html |title=Body scanner: more |publisher=Tek84 |date=2010-03-17 |accessdate=2013-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506113432/http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner-more.html |archivedate=2014-05-06 }} In a study published in the ''[[Archives of Internal Medicine]]'' on March 28, 2011 researchers at the University of California "calculated that fully implementing backscatter scanners would not significantly increase the lifetime risk of cancer for travelers."{{cite journal |last1= Mehta |first1= P.|last2=Smith-Bindman|first2=R.|title=Airport Full-Body Screening: What Is the Risk? |journal= Archives of Internal Medicine|year= 2011|issn= 0003-9926|doi= 10.1001/archinternmed.2011.105|pmid= 21444831 |volume= 171|issue= 12|pages= 1112–5|pmc= 3936792}}{{cite web|title=Analysis Suggests Cancer Risk of Backscatter Airport Scanners is Low|url=http://www.ucsf.edu/news/2011/03/9619/analysis-suggests-cancer-risk-backscatter-airport-scanners-low |first=Jason |last=Bardi|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate= 2011-03-31 |publisher= UCSF}} The researchers calculated that for every 100 million passengers who flew seven one-way flights, there would be one additional cancer.{{Cite news|title= Cancer risk is low, but possible in airport scanners |url= http://thechart.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/28/cancer-risk-is-low-but-possible-in-airport-scanners/|date=March 28, 2011 |accessdate=2011-03-31|work=CNN}}{{cite news|title=Airport security scans: What would your doctor do?|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/03/31/ep.airport.scanners/|first= Elizabeth |last= Cohen |date= March 31, 2011|work=CNN|accessdate= 2011-03-31}} ===Efficacy=== In March 2012, scientist and blogger Jonathan Corbett demonstrated the ineffectiveness of the technology by publishing a viral video showing how he was able to get a metal box through backscatter x-ray and millimeter wave scanners (including the currently-used "Automated Target Recognition" scanners) in two US airports.{{Citation | publisher = Word press | title = TSA out of our pants | date = 2012-03-06 | contribution-url = https://tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com/2012/03/06/1b-of-nude-body-scanners-made-worthless-by-blog-how-anyone-can-get-anything-past-the-tsas-nude-body-scanners/ | contribution = $ 1 B of TSA Nude Body Scanners Made Worthless by Blog – How Anyone Can Get Anything Past The Scanners}}.{{Citation | newspaper = PC mag | url = https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2401276,00.asp | title = Blogger Says TSA's Full-Body Scanners Can be Easily Duped}}. In April 2012, Corbett released a second video interviewing a TSA screener, who described firearms and simulated explosives passing through the scanners during internal testing and training.{{Citation | title = TSA out of our pants | contribution-url = http://tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com/2012/04/10/tsa-admits-1b-nude-body-scanner-fleet-worthless/ | publisher = Word press | date = 2012-04-10 | contribution = TSA Admits $ 1 B Nude Body Scanner Fleet Worthless!}}. Backscatter scanners installed by the TSA until 2013 were unable to screen adequately for security threats inside hats and head coverings, casts, prosthetics and loose clothing.{{cite web|url= http://www.queenstribune.com/deadline/Deadline_012011_SikhsCautioned.html |title=Sikhs Cautioned Over 'Random' Air Searches| first =Joseph | last = Orovic| newspaper =Queens Tribune}}{{cite web|url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/americas/2007/08/2008525141141752646.html|title=Sikh outrage at US airport security |publisher=Al Jazeera}} This technology limitation of current scanners often requires these persons to undergo additional screening by hand or other methods and can cause additional delay or feelings of harassment.{{cite web |url=http://www.cairchicago.org/2010/11/22/travel-advisory-know-your-rights-if-asked-to-undergo-new-tsa-enhanced-pat-downs |title=Travel advisory: Know Your Rights if Asked to Undergo New TSA 'Enhanced Pat-Downs' |publisher=CAIR-Chicago |accessdate=2013-09-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207120640/http://www.cairchicago.org/2010/11/22/travel-advisory-know-your-rights-if-asked-to-undergo-new-tsa-enhanced-pat-downs/ |archive-date=2013-12-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The next generation of backscatter scanners are able to screen these types of clothing, according to manufacturers; however, these machines are not currently in use in public airports.{{cite web|url=http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner.html |title=Body scanner |publisher=Tek84 |date=2010-03-17 |accessdate=2013-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208202236/http://tek84.com/bodyscanner.html |archivedate=2013-12-08 }} In Germany, field tests on more than 800,000 passengers over a 10-month trial period concluded that scanners were effective, but not ready to be deployed in German airports due to a high rate of false alarms.{{cite web | place = [[Germany|DE]] | url = http://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Pressemitteilungen/EN/2011/09/body_scanner.html;jsessionid=41683727D2038ECE4D11619DFD7236EF.2_cid156 | title = News – Test of full-body scanners: Effective, but not yet ready for nation-wide rollout | publisher = Bund | website = BMI | accessdate = 2013-09-02 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131202223138/http://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Pressemitteilungen/EN/2011/09/body_scanner.html;jsessionid=41683727D2038ECE4D11619DFD7236EF.2_cid156 | archive-date = 2013-12-02 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The Italian Civil Aviation Authority removed scanners from airports after conducting a study that revealed them to be inaccurate and inconvenient.{{cite web |url= http://epic.org/2010/09/tests-in-italy-raise-new-quest.html |title=Tests in Italy Raise New Questions About Airport Body Scanners |publisher= EPIC |accessdate= 2013-09-02}} The European Commission decided to effectively ban backscatter machines.{{cite web|last=Melnick |first=Meredith |url=http://healthland.time.com/2011/11/21/europe-bans-airport-x-ray-scanners-should-the-u-s-follow-suit/ |title=Europe Bans Airport X-Ray Scanners. Should the U.S. Follow Suit? | publisher = Time | website =Healthland |date=2011-11-21 |accessdate=2013-09-02}} In a 2011 staff report by Republican Members of Congress about the TSA, airport body scanners were described as "ineffective" and "easily thwarted."{{Citation|url=http://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/267126/house-gop-report-a-call-for-tsa-reform.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202111202/http://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/267126/house-gop-report-a-call-for-tsa-reform.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-12-02 |title=House GOP report: a call for TSA reform |publisher=Document cloud |format=PDF }} ==Safety regulations and standards== In the US, manufacturers of security related equipment can apply for protection under the SAFETY act, which limits their financial liability in product liability cases to the amount of their insurance coverage. The Rapiscan Secure 1000 was listed in 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.safetyact.gov/ |title=US government SAFETY act website |accessdate=2013-09-03}} In the US, an X-ray system can be considered to comply with requirements for general purpose security screening of humans if the device complies with American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Standard #N43.17.{{cite web |url= http://www.hps.org/hpssc/N43Status.html | publisher =Health Physics Society |title= Status |date=January 15, 2010 |accessdate= August 16, 2010}}{{cite web |url= http://hpschapters.org/2009AM/program/singlesession.php3?sessid=WPM-D |title= Chapters | publisher =Health Physics Society |date=August 9, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}} In the most general sense, N43.17 states that a device can be used for general purpose security screening of humans if the dose to the subject is less than 25 [[Röntgen equivalent man|μrems]] (0.25 [[sievert|μSv]]) per examination and complies with other requirements of the standard. Twenty-five micro-Rem is equal to the amount of background radiation every human is exposed to (from the air and soil) at sea level every 1.5 hours and is also equal to the radiation exposure from [[cosmic rays]] when travelling in an airplane at altitude for 2 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/rpdweb00/understand/calculate.html |title=US Environmental Protection Agency Radiation Dose Calculator |publisher=EPA |date=June 28, 2006 |accessdate=August 16, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100801013847/http://www.epa.gov/rpdweb00/understand/calculate.html | archivedate= 1 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Many types of X-ray systems can be designed to comply with ANSI N43.17 including transmission X-ray,{{cite web |url=http://www.saic.com/products/security/vacis-xpl/ |title=Products: X-ray passenger vehicle inspection VACIS XPL |publisher=SAIC |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910042527/http://www.saic.com/products/security/vacis-xpl/ |archivedate=10 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} backscatter X-ray and gamma ray systems. Not all backscatter X-ray devices necessarily comply with ANSI N43.17; only the manufacturer or end user can confirm compliance of a particular product to the standard. ANSI standards use a standard of measurement algorithm called "effective dose" that considers the different exposure of all parts of the body and then weights them differently. The interior of the human body is given more weight in this survey, and the exterior, including the skin organ, are given less weight. ==Technical countermeasures== Some people wish to prevent either the loss of privacy or the possibility of health problems or genetic damage that might be associated with being subjected to a backscatter X-ray scan. One company sells X-ray absorbing underwear which is said to have X-ray absorption equivalent to {{convert|0.5|mm|abbr=on}} of lead.{{cite web|url=http://rockyflatsgear.com/ |title=X-ray protection |publisher=Rocky flats gear |accessdate=2013-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901143535/http://www.rockyflatsgear.com/ |archivedate=2013-09-01 }} Another product, Flying Pasties, "are designed to obscure the most private parts of the human body when entering full body airport scanners," but their description does not seem to claim any protection from the X-ray beam penetrating the body of the person being scanned.{{cite web|url=http://www.flyingpasties.com/ |title= Flying Pasties |accessdate= 2013-09-03}} ==See also== * [[Visible Intermodal Prevention and Response team]] * [[Explosives trace-detection portal machine]] (puffer machine) * [[Future Attribute Screening Technology]] * [[Millimeter wave scanner]] * [[Full body scanner]] * [[Container Security Initiative]] * [[NYPD X-ray vans]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Backscatter X-ray}} * {{Citation | url = http://www.educatedearth.net/video.php?id=4170 | title = Z-Backscatter Van | publisher = Educated Earth | type = video}}: a backscatter x-ray, mounted on surveillance trucks. * {{Citation | url = https://www.usatoday.com/travel/news/2010-07-13-bodyscans13_ST_N.htm | title = Full-body scans of fliers set off debate over privacy, health | newspaper = USA today | date = 2010-07-13}}. * {{Citation|url=http://sxi.nre.ufl.edu/ |publisher=University of Florida |title=Research—High Resolution Scatter X-ray Imaging |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103114639/http://sxi.nre.ufl.edu/ |archivedate=2010-01-03 |df= }}. * {{Citation | url = http://www.articleworld.org/index.php/Backscatter_X-ray | title = Backscatter X-ray technology and risks | publisher = Article world}}. {{DEFAULTSORT:Backscatter X-Ray}} [[Category:Aviation security]] [[Category:Radiography]] [[Category:Explosive detection]]

{{Unreferenced|date=January 2014}}
[[File:Header-Unloading-into-Chaser-Bin.jpg|thumb|Combine unloading into chaser bin]] [[File:Chaser-Unloading-into-Semi.jpg|thumb|Chaser bin unloading into a grain hopper trailer.]] [[File:Two-Headers-unloading-into-Chaser-Bins.jpg|thumb|Two combines unloading into 2 chaser bins]]
A '''chaser bin''', also called '''grain cart''' or '''(grain) auger wagon''', is a [[trailer (vehicle)|trailer]] towed by a [[tractor]] with a built-in [[auger conveyor]] system, usually with a large capacity (from several hundred to over 1000 [[bushel]]s; around {{Convert|15|t|lb}} is average).
==Design== The typical setup of a chaser bin is a cross auger, which feeds the folding unload auger, which in turn empties the contents into waiting [[Grain hopper trailer]]s or [[Chaser bin#Mother bins|mother bins]].
The bins range in size, from 12T to 38T in most cases. Single axle bins usually can only handle a maximum of 20T of grain, with excess weight placing undue strain on the axle, potentially causing failure, especially on rough terrain. Bins above a capacity of 20T, tend to feature a "walking beam" chassis. This chassis design features an independent axle setup, allowing the bin to smoothly travel across ditches and divets, as well as more easily access fields where the road is higher than the field level. It also allows the load to be evenly distributed along the length of the chassis, further reducing the risk of axle failure when traveling over rough terrain, particularly with a full bin.
The design of the bins usually follows the same pattern regardless of capacity, with smooth flowing curves to allow the grain to easily unload via the cross auger. This also helps prevent the grain sticking to the walls of the bin, preventing corrosion.
The cross auger is smaller than the main unload auger, which allows the unload auger to expel the grain at a constant rate. The bins can also feature cross auger cut-offs, which allow the operator to choke the feed rate to the unload auger if it starts struggling. Unload augers can empty a full bin in a matter of minutes, with 15" augers unloading at a rate of 6T per minute, and 19" augers unloading at 10T per minute.
==Usage== Chaser bins are typically used to transport [[harvest]]ed grain or corn over fields from a [[combine harvester|header]] to a [[semi-trailer truck|road train]] or other hauling device which is used to cover larger distances over roads. The use of a chaser bin allows the harvester to operate continuously, eliminating the need to stop and unload.
These bins usually require tractors with large power outputs and are popular on the generally larger and more open fields of the [[United States]] and [[Australia]], though usage in [[Europe]] is increasing.
== Mother bins== [[File:Mother-Bin-as-a-Static-Collection-point.jpg|thumb|Mother bin as a static collection point]] Mother bins, also known as "field bins" in Queensland, offer the farmer a convenient storage location while harvesting. They offer a large storage capacity ranging from 55T to 130T. They are usually located on a paddock road at the entrance to the paddock being harvested, and allowing chaser bins to unload into them and offering truck drivers a more convenient location to fill grain into their semi-trailers. This also assists in reducing unnecessary soil compaction, by reducing the number of road trains on a given paddock.
Mother bins are not to be confused with chaser bins. Although they both hold and unload grain in the same manner, mother bins, are not designed to be used as chaser bins. They are only to be moved when empty, or if needed at a maximum of 25% full on smooth terrain only. They are designed to be a static collection point only.
== External links == {{Commonscat-inline|Auger wagons}}

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:1941cg.jpg|1941 Mystery Dial Code-O-Graph|right]] -->
The '''Code-O-Graph''' is a field [[cipher]] device and identifier from the [[Captain Midnight]] radio serial. In the story line they were used by agents of the Secret Squadron, a paramilitary organization headed by [[Captain Midnight]]. In addition to their use as devices in the radio program, they were offered as [[radio premiums]] for listeners. As radio premiums, listeners sent in an [[Ovaltine]] [[proof of purchase]] with their names and addresses.
The Code-O-Graph incorporates a [[cipher disk]], a cryptological device, but the letters in the message were substituted by numbers, probably to avoid ambiguity for broadcast messages. On the radio show, usually once a week, a message would be sent that could be deciphered by listeners. Each message, only a few words long, was invariably a clue to the upcoming episode.
==Models== The first Code-O-Graph, called the "Mystery Dial" unit,was introduced in 1941, as a device to enable Secret Squadron agents in the field to send and receive secure messages. It was in badge form, as were the next three models. The front of the badge displayed the number and cipher alphabet scales. The reverse had two windows, one labeled "Master Code"; the other, "Super Code." each window was used for cipher key settings. As an example, if the cipher was designated as "Master Code 3," it meant that the movable rotor was to spun so that the number 3 would appear in the window labeled "Master Code." This setting would align the number and cipher alphabet scales correctly to decipher a message.
The second Code-O-Graph was the "Photo-Matic" unit. The badge had a space for a picture of the owner, to make it a photo-ID badge.
The advent of World War II affected the Code-O-Graph availability: the two previous models were made of [[brass]], and the attack on [[Pearl Harbor]], which propelled the United States into World War II, caused the U.S. Government to impose restrictions on manufacturing materials. Copper and brass were considered critical materials, and most of the materials were diverted to war activities. This precluded brass being used to manufacture novelties like radio premiums.
The Photo-Matic Code-O-Graph, although not distributed until 1942, was manufactured prior to the Pearl Harbor attack. Since it, and its predecessor, were undated, the newer Code-O-Graph was used for the 1943 and 1944 seasons as well as the 1942, making it the Code-O-Graph with the longest service life. The cipher setting scheme was similar to the 1941 Mystery Dial model, but there was only one cipher setting window, labeled "Master Code."
By late 1944, Ovaltine scraped together enough material to manufacture another Code-O-Graph, the 1945 "Magni-Magic" Code-O-Graph. This unit used stamped sheet steel for the badge bodies, painted with "gold" paint to look similar to the earlier brass badges. The cipher disk element was made of injection-molded plastic, with the center of the disk knob in the form of a magnifying lens. The production was limited, and it was the only model of which supplies were completely exhausted.
The 1945 model altered the cipher-key setting scheme. The new method was to align one of the letters on the alphabet scale to a numeral on the number scale. For instance, the "Master Code X-15" setting meant that the letter X would be moved until it was next to the number 15 on the number scale. The advantage with the new scheme was that a total of 676 possible key setting combinations could be used. The disadvantage was that each key compromised one letter-number pair.
The 1946 model was the "Mirro-Flash" unit, the first postwar Code-O-Graph, and the last in badge form. Since the war had ended, the new badge was made of stamped sheet brass, and the plastic "dial" element had a small circular mirror for signaling by heliography. It used the same cipher-key setting methodology as its immediate predecessor. This practice was used for the 1947 and 1949 models as well.
The 1947 model was the first in non-badge form. It was in the shape of a police-style whistle, with the cipher elements along one side. It was called the "Whistle Code-O-Graph," possibly the least imaginative name of the series.
The 1948 model, the "Mirro-Magic" unit, was a circular product, manufactured of brass, aluminum, plastic, and steel. The cipher letters and numbers could only be seen one at a time through windows on the front. The design had the cipher alphabet and number disks coupled by friction, and there was often slippage when trying to decipher a message. Unlike any other Code-O-Graph, the cipher-key settings utilized a pointer on the back, and a number scale from 1 through 26. Each would increment the positioning of the two scales.
[[File:1949 Captain Midnight Key-O-Matic Code-O-Graph.jpg|1941 Key-O-Matic Code-O-Graph|right]]
The last Code-O-Graph was the "Key-O-Matic" unit. Possibly to compensate for the slippage of the 1948 unit's elements, the cipher alphabet and number scales were placed on interlocking gears, preventing any slippage. Resetting the cipher elements utilized a small key that was inserted into slots over one of the gears, which could be disengaged, using the key and a leaf spring as a simple clutch mechanism.
==References in popular culture== A Code-O-Graph-like [[secret decoder ring]] was featured in the 1983 movie ''[[A Christmas Story]]'' as an object of both joy and frustration. Richard Farina - Been Down So Long It Looks Like Up To Me (1966) [https://www.amazon.com/Been-Down-Looks-Twentieth-Century-Classics/dp/0140189300] - talks about it in Chapter one, listing it first in the list of the "only possessions and necessities of his life." (p. 4, in the 1983 Penguin edition)
==References== * ''Tomart's Price Guide to Radio Premium and Cereal Box Collectibles'' Tom Tumbusch (Radnor, PA: Wallace-Homestead, 1991 {{ISBN|0-87069-635-1}})
[[Category:Encryption devices]] [[Category:History of cryptography]] [[Category:1930s toys]]

{{unreferenced|date=March 2016}} In long, slender structural elements — such as columns or [[truss]] bars — an increase of compressive force ''F'' leads to [[structural failure]] due to [[buckling]] at lower stress than the [[compressive strength]].
Compressive stress has stress units (force per unit area), usually with [[negative and non-negative numbers|negative]] values to indicate the compaction. However, in [[geotechnical engineering]], compressive stress is represented with [[negative and non-negative numbers|positive]] values.
Compressive stress is defined in the same way as the tensile stress but it has negative values so as to express the compression since dL has the opposite direction. ( L is the length of the object.)
Compression stress= -( F/A)
Where F= Force applied on the object.
A= Area of cross section of the object.
[[Category:Materials science]]
{{Engineering-stub}}
